articles.headline: Sweeping Effects as Broadband Moves to Meters
articles.snippet: Broadband companies are moving toward a strategy called usage-based billing, which will charge tiers of pricing based on how much people use their Internet at home.
articles.abstract: Broadband companies are moving toward a strategy called usage-based billing, which will charge tiers of pricing based on how much people use their Internet at home.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — The broadband era began with the expectation that Internet connections were like buffets — all you can eat, 24 hours a day. But users are now being prodded to think about how much they’re consuming.

articles.headline: F.B.I. Says 24 Are Arrested in Credit Card Theft Plan
articles.snippet: The computer crime arrests were made on four continents in an undercover operation.
articles.abstract: The computer crime arrests were made on four continents in an undercover operation.
articles.lead_paragraph: For hackers in search of information like credit card numbers and software to spy on computers, the site called Carder Profit appeared to be a veritable eBay for thieves.

articles.headline: Why Germany Will Pay Up to Save the Euro
articles.snippet: Chancellor Angela Merkel must know that dissolving the currency would cost Germany much more than maintaining it.
articles.abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel must know that dissolving the currency would cost Germany much more than maintaining it.
articles.lead_paragraph: To go by the pronouncements coming out of Germany over the last couple of weeks, you might naturally conclude that the euro is toast. Speaking before Parliament, Chancellor Angela Merkel broadly rejected “counterproductive” proposals to pool Europe’s resources to help floundering Mediterranean nations. Germany’s “strength is not infinite,” she stressed.

articles.headline: Valuing a News Corp. Breakup
articles.snippet: Breaking down the News Corporation might show that both parts of the media conglomerate — its vast entertainment holdings and its smaller publishing arm — could yield a significant jump in shareholder value.
articles.abstract: Breaking down the News Corporation might show that both parts of the media conglomerate — its vast entertainment holdings and its smaller publishing arm — could yield a significant jump in shareholder value.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, it’s called the “Murdoch discount.”
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Public Exchanges Duel With Newcomers Over Trade Transparency
articles.snippet: NYSE Euronext asked regulators to allow it to create a market that is similar to the unregulated “dark markets,” and Nasdaq said it had similar plans.
articles.abstract: NYSE Euronext asked regulators to allow it to create a market that is similar to the unregulated “dark markets,” and Nasdaq said it had similar plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: While most people trading stocks at home imagine their orders zipping from their brokers onto one of the nation’s stock exchanges, almost none of the trades go anywhere near those public markets.

articles.headline: Spanish Officials Hailed Banks as Crisis Built
articles.snippet: Spanish financial leaders, who took positions assessing global financial risk for the International Monetary Fund, failed to sound alarms as Spain edged closer to a real estate and banking crisis.
articles.abstract: Spanish financial leaders, who took positions assessing global financial risk for the International Monetary Fund, failed to sound alarms as Spain edged closer to a real estate and banking crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Spain edged closer to a real estate and banking crisis that led to its recent bank bailout, Spanish financial leaders in influential positions mostly played down concerns that something might go terribly wrong.

articles.headline: At News Corp., a Plan to Sever Publishing Arm
articles.snippet: The News Corporation is in talks to sever its publishing assets from its lucrative entertainment units.
articles.abstract: The News Corporation is in talks to sever its publishing assets from its lucrative entertainment units.
articles.lead_paragraph: After years of defending its financially underperforming newspapers, News Corporation is now in talks to break up the company and sever its publishing assets, like The Wall Street Journal, The Times of London and The New York Post, from its lucrative entertainment units.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: S.E.C. Said to Be Poised to Sue Fund Manager
articles.snippet: Philip A. Falcone, the hedge fund manager, will fight any charges filed against him, his lawyer said. The S.E.C. has been looking at a $113 million loan Mr. Falcone made from his fund.
articles.abstract: Philip A. Falcone, the hedge fund manager, will fight any charges filed against him, his lawyer said. The S.E.C. has been looking at a $113 million loan Mr. Falcone made from his fund.
articles.lead_paragraph: His wireless dreams all but dashed, billions of dollars lost and investors swearing him off, Philip A. Falcone has been a colorful exhibit of how quickly fortunes can turn in the hedge fund world.

articles.headline: Barclays Settles Regulators’ Claims Over Manipulation of Key Rates
articles.snippet: Barclays has agreed to pay more than $450 million to resolve accusations that it attempted to manipulate crucial interest rates, the first settlement in a sprawling global investigation involving many of the world’s biggest banks.
articles.abstract: Barclays has agreed to pay more than $450 million to resolve accusations that it attempted to manipulate crucial interest rates, the first settlement in a sprawling global investigation involving many of the world’s biggest banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Regulators delivered the first blow in a major investigation into whether big banks had improperly set key interest rates that affected how consumers and companies borrowed money around the world.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Mark Scott
